title: Historical Stock Price Performance of Paramount Global during Significant Market Events

content.text: During the infamous 1929 stock market crash, also known as the Great Crash or Black Tuesday, Paramount Global experienced a significant decline in its stock price. As panic spread throughout the market, investors rushed to sell their shares, causing a sharp drop in prices. The crash marked the beginning of the Great Depression, characterized by a prolonged economic downturn.

The 2008 financial crisis, triggered by the collapse of Lehman Brothers and the bursting of the housing bubble, had a substantial impact on Paramount Global's stock price. As the crisis unfolded, stock markets worldwide plummeted due to widespread fear and uncertainty. Paramount Global, like many other companies, experienced a severe decline in its stock price during this period.

The dotcom bubble, a speculative frenzy in the late 1990s and early 2000s surrounding internet companies, eventually burst in 2000. Paramount Global, being outside the tech sector, did not have a direct involvement in the bubble. However, the burst had ripple effects on the overall market sentiment, leading to a decline in stock prices across various sectors, including Paramount Global.

The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in early 2020 had a profound impact on global financial markets, including Paramount Global's stock price. As countries implemented lockdown measures and economic activity stalled, stock markets experienced a rapid and steep decline. Paramount Global's stock price also witnessed a significant drop during the pandemic-induced market crash.

Following significant market events such as crashes, there have been periods of recovery and rallies. For example, after World War II, as economies rebuilt, stock markets experienced substantial growth. Paramount Global's stock price likely benefited from these post-war rallies, reflecting the broader market trends.

In more recent history, technological advancements and shifts in the business landscape have influenced Paramount Global's stock price performance. For instance, the rise of streaming services and digital content consumption disrupted traditional media industries, including film studios like Paramount. Consequently, developments in technology and market dynamics have had an impact on the company's stock performance.

During periods of economic growth and boom, such as the 'Roaring Twenties' in the 1920s or the expansionary periods of the late 20th century, Paramount Global's stock price likely experienced positive trends. Economic prosperity generally correlates with increased consumer spending and business performance, which can drive stock prices higher.

Regulatory changes and antitrust cases have occasionally affected Paramount Global's stock price. For instance, in the past, the company has faced legal challenges related to antitrust violations. These cases can have implications for the company's reputation and financial standing, potentially influencing its stock performance.

news.headline: Mattel to make 'American Girl' movie after 'Barbie' success
news.summary: Mattel said on Wednesday it was planning to make a live-action feature film based on its "American Girl" doll line with Paramount Pictures and Temple Hill Entertainment, after the box-office success of its "Barbie" movie earlier this year.  Shares of the toymaker rose marginally in extended trading after it also said Lindsey Anderson Beer, who wrote the Netflix film "Sierra Burgess is a Loser", would write the screenplay and produce the film.  Margot Robbie-starrer "Barbie", released in July, recorded the biggest opening of the year, which Mattel in October said was expected to contribute more than $125 million towards its Dolls segment's key gross billings measure in 2023.

news.headline: Could there be more media mergers & acquisitions in 2024?
news.summary: Paramount (PARA) majority owner Shari Redstone is reportedly considering selling the entertainment giant to Skydance media, while Altice USA (ATUS) is considering selling its news arm, Cheddar News, to private equity firm Regent. Both potential deals raise questions around the state of streaming services and potential M&A activity heading into 2024. Matthew Harrigan, Benchmark Analyst, joins Yahoo Finance to give insights into why he feels both headlines are "a bit of a surprise," though he also notes that it media conglomerates are looking to get "more scale" relative to competition from the likes of Netflix (NFLX), Disney (DIS), Amazon (AMZN) and others.  For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Yahoo Finance Live.

news.headline: Paramount: Potential Sale Rumors Spurred A Massive Recovery (Rating Downgrade)
news.summary: Speculation of a change in ownership has fueled the recent upside in Paramount Global's stock. See why I downgrade PARA from buy to hold.

news.headline: Why Paramount Global Stock Popped Today
news.summary: Shares of Paramount Global  (NASDAQ: PARA) (NASDAQ: PARA.A) closed up 12% on Friday after Puck News reported that the entertainment conglomerate is the subject of takeover interest from Skydance Media and RedBird Capital Partners.  Citing three sources familiar with the situation, the media outlet said that Skydance and RedBird are considering indirectly taking control of Paramount -- by acquiring media company National Amusements, which currently owns around 77% of Paramount's Class A voting shares.

news.headline: Shari Redstone weighs options for Paramount as Skydance eyes bid for studio
news.summary: Paramount Global’s controlling shareholder has held talks about a sale of the legendary Hollywood studio and other assets to Skydance, the production company behind Top Gun: Maverick, according to people familiar with the company controlled by Shari Redstone.  Skydance, whose shareholders include the Ellison family and RedBird Capital Partners, has emerged as a leading contender to take over Redstone’s National Amusements, which has a controlling stake in Paramount.* The two companies have co-produced a series of movies.

news.headline: Paramount in talks for sale to Skydance as Shari Redstone explores options
news.summary: Paramount Global has held talks about a sale of its legendary Hollywood studio and other assets to Skydance, the production company behind Top Gun: Maverick, according to sources familiar with the company controlled by Shari Redstone.  Skydance, whose shareholders include the Ellison family and RedBird Capital Partners, has emerged as a leading contender to take over Paramount in part due to the strong ties between the two companies, which have co-produced a series of movies.  The conversations were at a very early stage and there was no certainty they would lead to a deal, according to two knowledgeable sources.

news.headline: S&P 500 Gains and Losses Today: Paramount Global Shares Soar Amid Sale Talk
news.summary: The S&P 500 gained 0.4% on Friday, Dec. 8, 2023, as reports on employment and inflation expectations helped boost optimism that the economy won't crash.

news.headline: Paramount Global Shares Soar on Reports of a Possible Sale of the Media Giant
news.summary: Paramount Global (PARA) was the best-performing stock in the S&P 500 as reports swirled that the entertainment giant might be sold.  The reports from Deadline and Puck suggested that film producer David Ellison, CEO of Skydance Media, and private equity firm RedBird Capital Partners are considering acquiring the company.  Deadline explained that any effort to buy Paramount likely would require taking control of theater operator National Amusements, which holds 77% of Paramount’s Class A voting shares.

news.headline: Paramount Global Is Soaring on M&A Talk, So Let's Check the Trends
news.summary: Paramount Global  is trading higher Friday on a new report of sale considerations (David Ellison and RedBird Capital are eying the company, according to media reports).  The Wall Street Journal reported on December 1 that Paramount and Apple  are in talks about bundling their video streaming services together.  The On-Balance-Volume (OBV) line declined into early November and has turned higher.

news.headline: 2023 in books: Protests, bannings and the rise of AI helped shape the story of publishing
news.summary: Book publishing in 2023 was a story of cooling sales and rising conflict, marked by legal action, protests, censorship and the impact of forces well beyond the industry.  Colleen Hoover, one of BookTok's signature authors, continued her reign as the country’s top-selling author, even without releasing a new book in 2023.  Three of her novels were among the top 10 sellers as tracked by Circana, with other popular releases including novels by two authors, Sarah J. Maas and Rebecca Yarros, regarded as leaders of romantasy, a newly branded genre that combines romance and fantasy.

news.headline: What's next for streamers after Hollywood strikes wrap up?
news.summary: Hollywood studios and streaming platforms are entering comeback mode from the Hollywood strikes that halted major productions and slowed down fresh content output. Brightcove (BCOV) CEO Marc DeBevoise sits down in-studio with Yahoo Finance Live to highlight how streaming bundling strategies and ad-tier subscription prices may bring business back to streaming services like Netflix (NFLX), Amazon (AMZN), Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD), Disney+ (DIS), and Paramount (PARA). "The free ad-supported streaming television revolution... has really ramped up the opportunity for advertising on these services. You'll see each subscription service also have an ad-supported with lower priced tier over time," DeBevoise says, adding: "The winner there is streaming overall." For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Yahoo Finance Live.
